hypotheses.title: Detection of ClickFix DNS Tunneling Attacks Using nslookup for Malware Delivery
hypotheses.description: Attackers are increasingly using DNS tunneling via the nslookup command as part of ClickFix social engineering campaigns to deliver second-stage payloads (e.g., ModeloRAT, StealC). This technique bypasses traditional command-line restrictions and leverages built-in Windows tools to evade detection. We are hunting for suspicious DNS queries containing encoded payloads in response fields.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1059.003 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell

data_sources_needed.specific_data: DNS query logs, especially TXT/NULL record queries and Name field parsing in responses
tools: DNS logging infrastructure (e.g., BIND, Cisco Stealthwatch), SIEM (Splunk, Sentinel), EDR (CrowdStrike, SentinelOne)

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process creation logs with command-line arguments containing 'nslookup' and suspicious patterns (e.g., 'nslookup -q=TXT', 'nslookup <domain> | findstr Name:')
tools: EDR, Sysmon (Event ID 1), Windows Event Logs (4688/1)

hunting_tactics.description: Search for DNS queries with unusually long or base64-like subdomains and responses containing 'Name:' followed by encoded data or PowerShell commands
sample_queries: index=netdns sourcetype=dns * | where match(query, "^[a-zA-Z0-9]{30,}") OR match(query, "[a-f0-9]{16,}")
index=security_logs EventCode=4688 CommandLine=*nslookup* AND (CommandLine=*findstr* OR CommandLine=*|*) | table CommandLine, User, Hostname
hunting_tactics.look_for: nslookup commands with non-standard flags (e.g., -q=TXT), chained with pipe operators or findstr, and responses containing base64-encoded strings or PowerShell scripts

hunting_tactics.description: Identify suspicious command-line chains where nslookup is used to retrieve and parse data for execution
sample_queries: index=windows_logs EventCode=4688 CommandLine=*nslookup* AND (CommandLine=*findstr* OR CommandLine=*powershell* OR CommandLine=*cmd.exe*)
hunting_tactics.look_for: nslookup followed by parsing of 'Name:' response field to extract and execute payloads (e.g., via PowerShell or cmd /c)

network_patterns: DNS queries with unusually long subdomains (>30 chars), DNS TXT/NULL queries with high entropy responses
DNS responses containing 'Name:' followed by encoded strings
other_indicators: Use of 'Name:' field in DNS responses as payload channel

recommended_actions: Isolate affected hosts and capture memory/disk images
Review DNS logs for similar patterns across the network
Block nslookup usage via AppLocker/WDAC if not required
Update EDR rules to flag nslookup + findstr/powershell chains

hypotheses.title: Hunting for OpenClaw AI Agent Configuration Theft via Infostealers
hypotheses.description: Information-stealing malware has been observed exfiltrating OpenClaw (formerly Clawdbot/Moltbot) configuration files, including API keys, gateway tokens, and agent settings. This indicates attackers are targeting AI agent identities and digital 'souls'—a new attack vector beyond traditional credential theft. We are hunting for evidence of OpenClaw-related files being accessed or exfiltrated by infostealers.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials in Files

data_sources_needed.specific_data: File access logs for OpenClaw configuration paths, process injection into agent processes, API key access patterns
tools: EDR (SentinelOne, CrowdStrike), Sysmon (Event ID 11/15), File Integrity Monitoring

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Anomalous API token usage, unusual OAuth grants to third-party services
tools: Okta, Azure AD Audit Logs, SIEM

hunting_tactics.description: Search for access to OpenClaw configuration directories and files (e.g., ~/.clawdbot, ~/.openclaw, ClawHub)
sample_queries: index=endpoint_logs (file_path=*openclaw* OR file_path=*clawdbot* OR file_path=*clawhub*) AND (access_type=read OR access_type=modify)
hunting_tactics.look_for: Read/write access to OpenClaw config files (e.g., config.json, tokens.json, gateway_config.yaml), especially from non-user processes (e.g., infostealers like Lumma, RedLine)

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Credential Theft via AI Agent Processes
hunting_tactics.description: Detect infostealer processes accessing AI agent memory or configuration
sample_queries: index=endpoint_logs (process_name=*LummaStealer* OR process_name=*RedLine* OR process_name=*StealC*) AND (file_path=*openclaw* OR file_path=*clawdbot*)
hunting_tactics.look_for: Infostealer processes reading OpenClaw config files or environment variables containing gateway tokens or API keys

network_patterns: Outbound connections to known infostealer C2 (e.g., Telegram channels, Discord webhooks) with config file payloads

recommended_actions: Rotate all OpenClaw API keys and gateway tokens immediately if found
Audit AI agent permissions and revoke unnecessary scopes
Deploy EDR rules to block infostealer execution and monitor config file access

hypotheses.title: Detection of AI-Assisted Malware C2 via Web Browsing Features (e.g., Copilot, Grok)
hypotheses.description: AI assistants with web browsing capabilities (e.g., Microsoft Copilot, xAI Grok) have been weaponized as stealthy C2 relays. Attackers abuse their URL-fetching features to receive commands and exfiltrate data, blending into legitimate enterprise traffic. We are hunting for anomalous web requests from AI assistant processes to suspicious domains or encoded payloads.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1559.002 - Inter-Process Communication: Dynamic Data Exchange

data_sources_needed.specific_data: HTTPS traffic logs from AI assistant processes (e.g., copilot.exe, grok.exe), URL fetch patterns, TLS SNI anomalies
tools: TLS inspection proxies, Zeek logs, SIEM, EDR

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process execution logs for AI assistants with web browsing enabled, network calls to non-standard endpoints
tools: EDR, Sysmon (Event ID 1), Windows Event Logs

hunting_tactics.description: Detect AI assistants making unexpected outbound HTTPS requests to non-MS/GA domains or with encoded payloads
sample_queries: index=netflow (process_name=*copilot* OR process_name=*grok*) AND NOT (dest_domain IN ("*.microsoft.com", "*.openai.com", "*.x.ai", "*.google.com"))
index=sysmon EventID=3 (process_name=*copilot* OR process_name=*grok*) AND dest_port=443 AND NOT dest_ip IN (known_good_ips)
hunting_tactics.look_for: AI assistants (copilot.exe, grok.exe) making outbound HTTPS requests to unknown domains, especially with base64-encoded paths or POST bodies

hunting_tactics.description: Identify AI assistants fetching URLs with suspicious patterns (e.g., long base64 strings, obfuscated endpoints)
sample_queries: index=proxy_logs (user_agent=*copilot* OR user_agent=*grok*) AND (url=*base64* OR url=*%3D* OR url=*%2B* OR url=*%2F*)
index=sysmon EventID=1 (CommandLine=*copilot* OR CommandLine=*grok*) AND CommandLine=*fetch* AND CommandLine=*(http*base64*)
hunting_tactics.look_for: AI assistant processes using web browsing features to fetch URLs containing encoded data (e.g., 'https://evil[.]com/cmd?d=base64encodedpayload')

network_patterns: HTTPS to non-whitelisted domains, high-frequency short-lived connections, POST requests with base64 payloads
other_indicators: AI assistants with web browsing enabled making non-user-initiated network calls

recommended_actions: Disable web browsing features in AI assistants for non-essential users
Block outbound HTTPS to unknown domains from AI assistant processes
Monitor for AI assistant processes accessing sensitive endpoints (e.g., internal APIs, credential stores)

hypotheses.title: Hunting for DKnife AitM Framework Exploitation via Router Compromise
hypotheses.description: The DKnife framework, used by China-linked actors since 2019, hijacks routers and edge devices to perform Adversary-in-the-Middle (AitM) attacks, including deep-packet inspection, traffic manipulation, and malware delivery. We are hunting for signs of router compromise (e.g., unexpected firmware changes, unusual traffic patterns) and DKnife-specific implants.

data_sources_needed.specific_data: TLS inspection logs, DNS traffic anomalies, unexpected certificate changes, router management traffic
Router firmware hashes, SSH keys, management interface access logs
tools: Network scanning tools (Nmap), EDR, Configuration management (Ansible, Puppet)

hunting_tactics.description: Detect unauthorized firmware changes or unexpected router behavior (e.g., new SSH keys, modified configs)
sample_queries: index=router_logs (event=firmware_update OR event=config_change) AND NOT (source=known_admin OR user=known_admin)
index=network_scan (port=22 OR port=80 OR port=443) AND (service=ssh AND key_changed=true) AND (device_type=router OR device_type=firewall)
hunting_tactics.look_for: Unexpected SSH key changes, firmware checksum mismatches, or new admin accounts on routers/firewalls

hunting_tactics.description: Identify traffic anomalies consistent with AitM (e.g., TLS downgrade attempts, unexpected certificate chains)
sample_queries: index=tls_inspection (cert_chain_changed=true OR cert_issuer_changed=true) AND NOT (source_ip IN (known_good_ips))
index=zeek (ssl_version=TLSv1.0 OR ssl_version=TLSv1.1) AND (dest_port=443) AND (client_hello_sni=* AND server_hello_cipher=*unusual*)
hunting_tactics.look_for: Unexpected TLS version downgrades, certificate mismatches, or traffic rerouting through unknown intermediaries

network_patterns: Unusual DNS responses with unexpected A records, TLS handshakes with unknown CAs, router management traffic to non-admin IPs
other_indicators: Router firmware hashes matching known DKnife implants (e.g., 'dknife_router_v3.bin')
SSH keys added to routers without admin approval

recommended_actions: Audit all router firmware versions and compare against known-good baselines
Disable remote management on edge devices unless absolutely necessary
Deploy network segmentation to limit lateral movement from compromised routers

hypotheses.title: Detection of Phobos Ransomware via Compromised Credentials and RaaS Infrastructure
hypotheses.description: Phobos ransomware operators have been actively targeting organizations via compromised credentials and RaaS infrastructure. Polish authorities recently arrested a suspect linked to Phobos, with evidence including stolen credentials, server IPs, and logins. We are hunting for credential stuffing, lateral movement using stolen credentials, and Phobos-specific artifacts (e.g., encrypted files with .phobos extension).

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Failed login attempts, password spray events, unusual geographic logins
tools: Azure AD Identity Protection, Okta, SIEM

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process execution logs for ransomware tools (e.g., encryptors), file modification patterns
tools: EDR, Sysmon (Event ID 11/15), File Integrity Monitoring

hunting_tactics.description: Search for high-volume failed logins followed by successful logins from anomalous locations
sample_queries: index=auth_logs (event=failed_login) AND (user=* AND source_ip=*) | stats count by user, source_ip | where count > 50
index=auth_logs (event=success_login) AND (source_ip NOT IN (known_good_ips)) AND (user IN (recent_failed_users))
hunting_tactics.look_for: Credential stuffing patterns: >50 failed logins in 10 minutes, followed by a successful login from an unusual IP or location

hunting_tactics.description: Detect Phobos-specific file encryption patterns and artifacts
sample_queries: index=endpoint_logs (file_path=* AND file_extension=.phobos) OR (file_path=* AND file_name LIKE '%Phobos%' OR file_name LIKE '%DECRYPT%')
index=sysmon EventID=11 (TargetFilename=* AND TargetFilename LIKE '%.phobos%') OR (TargetFilename=* AND TargetFilename LIKE '%DECRYPT%')
hunting_tactics.look_for: Files with .phobos extension, files named 'DECRYPT_INSTRUCTIONS.txt', or rapid file modification across large datasets

network_patterns: Outbound connections to Phobos C2 (e.g., Telegram bots, dark web forums) with encrypted data payloads
other_indicators: Stolen credentials from past breaches (e.g., ShinyHunters leak), use of RDP/SSH with compromised credentials

recommended_actions: Reset all credentials for compromised accounts and enforce MFA
Block known Phobos C2 domains/IPs at the firewall
Deploy EDR rules to detect ransomware encryption patterns and勒索软件 behavior

unique_mitre_techniques: T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials in Files
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1559.002 - Inter-Process Communication: Dynamic Data Exchange
T1059.003 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
